article.title: Left-right model with TeV fermionic dark matter and unification

choices: The evolution of the Higgs potential with energy scale.
The running of the inverse gauge couplings with energy scale.
The mass spectrum of the scalar particles in the model.
The branching ratios of the WR boson.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 depict regarding the X<sub>1/2</sub> particle?
choices: Branching ratios of X<sub>1/2</sub> decays for different M<sub>WR</sub>.
Decay time of X<sub>1/2</sub> as a function of its mass for different M<sub>WR</sub> and mass splittings.
Relic density of X<sub>1/2</sub> for different M<sub>WR</sub> values.
Production cross-section of X<sub>1/2</sub> at different collision energies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the curves in Figure 3 represent in the context of dark matter?
choices: Regions in the M<sub>1</sub>-M<sub>2</sub> plane excluded by direct detection experiments.
Regions in the M<sub>1</sub>-M<sub>2</sub> plane consistent with the measured dark matter relic density.
Predicted cross-section for dark matter annihilation for different M<sub>WR</sub> values.
The evolution of the dark matter relic density with the age of the universe.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Figure 4 provide about the WR and Z\' bosons?
choices: Their decay lengths within the LHC detectors.
The branching ratios of their decays to dark matter particles.
Their production cross sections times branching fractions into different channels at âˆšs = 14 TeV.
Their contribution to the muon anomalous magnetic moment.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the subscripts L and R denote in Formula (1)?
choices: Left-handed and Right-handed chiralities of the particles.
Lepton and Quark quantum numbers.
Lightest and heaviest mass eigenstates.
Large and Reduced coupling strengths.
